'''Language secessionism''' (also known as '''linguistic secessionism''' or '''linguistic separatism''') is an attitude supporting the separation of a [[language variety]] from the [[language]] to which it has hitherto been considered to belong, in order to make this variety considered as a distinct language. This phenomenon was first analyzed by Catalan [[sociolinguistics]]<ref>For example:
*STRUBELL Miquel (1991) "Catalan in Valencia: the story of an attempted secession", Swiss Academy of Social Science Colloquium on Standardization: Parpan / Chur (Grisons) 15–20 April 1991 *PRADILLA Miquel Àngel (1999) "El secessionisme lingüístic valencià", in: PRADILLA Miquel Àngel (1999) (ed.) ''La llengua catalana al tombant del mil·leni'', Barcelona: Empúries, p. 153-202. *Article "secessionisme lingüístic", in: RUIZ I SAN PASCUAL Francesc, & SANZ I RIBELLES Rosa, & SOLÉ I CAMARDONS Jordi (2001) ''Diccionari de sociolingüística,'' coll. Diccionaris temàtics, Barcelona: Enciclopèdia Catalana.</ref> but it can be ascertained in other parts of the world.
== In Catalan and Occitan ==
=== Common characteristics === In the [[Occitano-Romance languages|Occitano-Catalan language area]], language secessionism is a quite recent phenomenon that has developed only since the 1970s. Language secessionism affects both [[Occitan language|Occitan]] and [[Catalan language|Catalan]] languages with the following common features:<ref>SUMIEN Domergue (2006) ''La standardisation pluricentrique de l’occitan: nouvel enjeu sociolinguistique, développement du lexique et de la morphologie,'' coll. Publications de l’Association Internationale d’Études Occitanes 3, Turnhout: Brepols, p. 49.</ref>
* A breakaway from the tradition of Occitan and Catalan [[Language revitalization|revivalist movements]], which usually claim the unity of both languages since the 19th century. * An often deliberate ignorance of the tradition of [[Romance languages|Romance]] [[linguistics]] that also claims the unity of Occitan and Catalan.<ref>BEC Pierre (1970-71) (collab. Octave NANDRIS, Žarko MULJAČIĆ) ''Manuel pratique de philologie romane,'' Paris: Picard, 2 vol.</ref> * An exacerbation of the [[cultural identity]] [[Cultural linguistics|linked to dialects]], which secessionism considers as separate languages. * A lack of success (or a very marginal position) in [[linguistics|linguistic]] scientific research.<ref>Georg Kremnitz, "Une approche sociolinguistique", in F. Peter Kirsch, & Georg Kremnitz, & Brigitte Schlieben-Lange (2002) ''Petite histoire sociale de la langue occitane: usages, images, littérature, grammaires et dictionnaires'', coll. Cap al Sud, F-66140 Canet: Trabucaire, p. 109-111 [updated version and partial translation from: Günter Holtus, & Michael Metzeltin, & Christian Schmitt (1991) (dir.) ''Lexikon der Romanistischen Linguistik''. Vol. V-2: ''Okzitanisch, Katalanisch'', Tübingen: Niemeyer]</ref> * An active [[lobbying]] in regional political circles. * The support of a [[writing system]] or of any prescription, which breaks up linguistic unity and exaggerates dialectal particular features.
=== In Catalan === In [[Catalan language|Catalan]], there are three cases: * [[Valencian]] language secessionism, or [[blaverism]], appeared during the [[Spanish transition to democracy|democratic transition]] at the end of the 1970s, after the fall of [[Francoism]]. It is supported by some conservative and usually [[Spanish language|Castilian]]-speaking circles of the Valencian society, which are branded as "post-Francoist" by partisans of [[Catalan nationalism|Catalan unity]]. It has variable impact in the population: Valencian people usually name their language "Valencian" but are divided about the unity of Catalan: some people agree in that "Valencian" is just the regional name for "Catalan" but other people think that "Valencian" would be a distinct language from "Catalan". Blaverism has no impact in the scientific community of linguists. Valencian institutions and Valencian partisans of Catalan unity use the official norm of Catalan (as codified by [[Institut d'Estudis Catalans]] and [[Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua]]), while "Blavers" (partisans of blaverism) mostly write Valencian using a spin-off, nonstandard system called "normes del Puig". * [[Balearic dialect|Balearic language]] secessionism is quite marginal and is supported by a few cultural groups. It has very little impact in the population. It is included in a wider (but unorganized) tendency called "gonellisme", which struggles against the [[Language standardization|standardization]] of Catalan. * In [[Franja de Ponent]] (a Catalan-speaking strip in eastern [[Aragon]]), language secessionism is quite marginal. It appeared during the 2000s. It is supported only by a fraction of the already minority pro-[[Aragonese language|Aragonese]] movements, who overstate a so-called Aragonese [[Proto-language|ancestry]] in the Catalan spoken in Aragon.
=== In Occitan === There are three cases in [[Occitan language|Occitan]]: * In the [[Auvernhat]] dialect, language secessionism has been supported since the 1970s by [[Pierre Bonnaud]], who founded the ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Bonnaudian norm]]'', the group ''Cercle Terre d'Auvergne'' and the review ''Bïzà Neirà''. It has negligible impact in the population, where knowledge of the language is in any case at best residual. Auvernhat cultural circles are divided between the unitary vision of Occitan (associated with the Occitan ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|classical norm]]'') and secessionism (associated with ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Bonnaudian norm]]''). * In the [[Provençal dialect|Provençal]] dialect, language secessionism appeared during the [[1970s]] with Louis Bayle and has been reactivated since the [[1990s]] by Philippe Blanchet and groups like "Union Provençale" and "Collectif Provence". This secessionism supports the ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Mistralian norm]]'' (but it does not represent all Mistralian norm users, since some of them claim traditionally the unity of Occitan). It has little impact in the population, whose knowledge of the language is anyway residual. Provençal cultural circles are divided between the unitary vision (supported by users of both ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Mistralian norm]]'' and ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|classical norm]]'') and the secessionist vision (supported by one some users of the ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Mistralian norm]]''). The Regional Council of [[Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur]] voted a resolution on 5 December 2003 that approved the principle of the unity of "Occitan or Langue d'Oc" and the fact that Provençal is a part of it. * In the [[Gascon language|Gascon]] dialect, language secessionism is claimed since the 1990s by Jean Lafitte, who created during the 2000s a group called "Institut Béarnais et Gascon". It has negligible impact in the population. Lafitte's secessionism supports two original writing systems: one is a nonstandard spin-off from the ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|classical norm]]'' and the other one is a nonstandard spinoff from the ''[[Occitan language#Writing system|Mistralian norm]]''. Gascon cultural circles almost unanimously support the unitary vision of the Occitan language. In [[Aran Valley]] (a little Gascon Occitan-speaking area in [[Spain]]), [[Aranese]], the local variety of [[Gascon language|Gascon]], is officially recognized as a part of the [[Occitan language]]. The status of semi-autonomy of Aran Valley (1990) presents Gascon [[Aranese]] as "Aranese, the variety of the Occitan language peculiar to Aran ([https://web.archive.org/web/20070609045335/http://www6.gencat.net/llengcat/aran/a_marclegal.htm "Er aranés, varietat dera lengua occitana e pròpia d’Aran"]). Similarly, the status of autonomy of [[Catalonia]], as reformed in 2006, confirms it with the following expression: "The Occitan language, which is named Aranese in Aran" ([https://web.archive.org/web/20070609045335/http://www6.gencat.net/llengcat/aran/a_marclegal.htm "Era lengua occitana, denominada aranés en Aran"]).
==In Hindi and Urdu== The [[national language]] of [[Pakistan]] and [[official language]]s in many parts of [[India]], the [[Khariboli dialect]] has become the chief [[language variety]] for use in [[Hindi]] and [[Urdu]]. Grammatically, Hindi and Urdu [[Hindustani language|are the same]] but differ in their lexicons. Hindi tends to revitalize its [[Sanskrit]] words and [[Linguistic purism|purges words]] borrowed from [[Persian language|Persian]] and [[Arabic language|Arabic]] while Urdu does the opposite. In essence, apart from their scripts, the [[lexicon]] is what distinguishes Urdu and Hindi. Also, there are other [[Indo-Aryan languages]] that are classed as Hindi but are not necessarily the same as Hindi and Urdu. Their dialects are close to the [[Khariboli]] dialect, which sets the grammatical standard over other Indo-Aryan languages both far and near. These languages will tend to diverge, especially through the influence and accents of surrounding [[native languages]] in the communities.
In Pakistan, Western [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] or [[Lahnda languages]], with [[Saraiki dialect|Saraiki]] ([[Multani dialect|Multani]]), [[Panjistani]] (Mirpuri-Potohari), [[Hindko languages|Hindko]] (Peshawari-Kohati), [[Dogri language|Dogri]] and [[Eastern Panjabi language|Eastern Panjabi]]/Majhi as the principal standards, have been related linguistically to other Indo-Aryan languages.
== In Romanian == The official standard language of [[Moldova]] is identical to [[Romanian language|Romanian]]. However, its official name in that country is "Moldovan" and at least [[Vasile Stati]], a local linguist, has asserted that it is, in fact, a separate language in its own right.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}} During the Soviet era, the USSR authorities officially recognized and promoted [[Moldovans]] and [[Moldovan language|Moldovan]] as a distinct ethnicity and language. A [[Moldovan cyrillic alphabet|Cyrillic alphabet]] was introduced in the [[Moldovan SSR]] to reinforce this claim. Since 1989 the official language switched to the [[Romanian alphabet|Latin script]] and underwent the same language reforms as Romanian, but has retained its name, Moldovan.
Nowadays, the Cyrillic alphabet remains in official use only on the territories controlled by the breakaway authorities of the [[Transnistria|Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic]], where it is named "Moldovan", as opposed to the Latin script version used elsewhere, which the local authorities call "Romanian".
== In Serbo-Croatian ==<!-- do not change title, it links from other pages --> [[Serbo-Croatian]] has a strong structural unity, according to the vast majority of linguists who specialize in [[Slavic languages]].<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Comrie |editor1-first=Bernard |editor1-link=Bernard Comrie |editor2-last=Corbett |editor2-first=Greville G. |year=2002 |origyear=1st. Pub. 1993 |title=The Slavonic Languages |location=London & New York |publisher=Routledge |oclc=49550401 |lastauthoramp=y}}</ref> However, the language is spoken by populations that have strong, different, national consciousnesses: [[Bosniaks]], [[Croats]], [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrins]], and [[Serbs]].
Since the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]] in 1991, Serbo-Croatian has lost its unitary codification and its official unitary status. It is now divided into four official languages which follow separate codifications: [[Bosnian language]], [[Croatian language]], [[Montenegrin language]] and the [[Serbian language]].
The common Serbo-Croatian system still exists in a [[Sociolinguistics|(socio)]][[linguistic]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Kordić |first=Snježana |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |editor1-last=Krause |editor1-first=Marion |editor2-last=Sappok |editor2-first=Christian |title=Slavistische Linguistik 2002: Referate des XXVIII. Konstanzer Slavistischen Arbeitstreffens, Bochum 10.-12. September 2002 |series=Slavistishe Beiträge ; vol. 434 |publisher=Otto Sagner |pages=97–148 |language=German |chapter=Pro und kontra: "Serbokroatisch" heute |trans-chapter=Pro and contra: "Serbo-Croatian" nowadays |chapterurl=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/430499.PRO_UND_KONTRA_SERBOKROATISCH.PDF |location=Munich |year=2004 |isbn=3-87690-885-X |oclc=56198470 |archivedate=4 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69f5n0ek4?url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/430499.PRO_UND_KONTRA_SERBOKROATISCH.PDF |deadurl=no |accessdate=13 April 2015}} [http://data.onb.ac.at/rec/AC05094207 (ÖNB)]</ref> point of view: it is a [[Pluricentric language#Serbo-Croatian|pluricentric language]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Bunčić |first=Daniel |editor1-last=Kempgen |editor1-first=Sebastian |title=Deutsche Beiträge zum 14. Internationalen Slavistenkongress, Ohrid, 2008 |series=Welt der Slaven |publisher=Otto Sagner |page=93 |language=German |chapter=Die (Re-)Nationalisierung der serbokroatischen Standards |trans-chapter=The (Re-)Nationalisation of Serbo-Croatian Standards |location=Munich |year=2008 |oclc=238795822}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kordić |first=Snježana |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |year=2010 |language=Serbo-Croatian |title=Jezik i nacionalizam |trans-title=Language and Nationalism |url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/475567.Jezik_i_nacionalizam.pdf |deadurl=no |series=Rotulus Universitas |location=Zagreb |publisher=Durieux |pages=69–168 |isbn=978-953-188-311-5 |lccn=2011520778 |oclc=729837512 |ol=15270636W |archivedate= 8 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/690BiBe4T?url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/475567.Jezik_i_nacionalizam.pdf |accessdate=1 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> being cultivated through four voluntarily diverging [[variety (linguistics)#Standard varieties|normative varieties]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Gröschel |first=Bernhard| authorlink=Bernhard Gröschel |year=2009 |language=German |title=Das Serbokroatische zwischen Linguistik und Politik: mit einer Bibliographie zum postjugoslavischen Sprachenstreit |trans-title=Serbo-Croatian Between Linguistics and Politics: With a Bibliography of the Post-Yugoslav Language Dispute |series=Lincom Studies in Slavic Linguistics 34 |location=Munich |publisher=Lincom Europa |page=451 |isbn=978-3-929075-79-3 |oclc=428012015 |lccn=2009473660 |ol=15295665W}}</ref> [[Croatian language|Croatian]], [[Bosnian language|Bosnian]], [[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]], and [[Serbian language|Serbian]], which are sometimes considered as [[Ausbau language]]s.<ref>The [[Ausbau language]] concept was developed by linguist [[Heinz Kloss]]. See: * {{cite journal|author=Kloss, Heinz |authorlink=Heinz Kloss |title=Abstand languages and Ausbau languages |journal=Anthropological Linguistics |volume=9 |issue=7 |pages=29–41 |year=1967 |jstor=30029461 |oclc=482264773}} * {{cite book|last=Kloss |first=Heinz| authorlink=Heinz Kloss |year=1978 |origyear=1st. Pub. 1952, Munich: Pohl |language=German |title=Die Entwicklung neuer germanischer Kultursprachen von 1800|trans-title=The Development of New Germanic Cultural Languages Since 1800 |series=coll. Sprache der Gegenwart-Schriften des Instituts für Deutsche Sprache 37 |location=Düsseldorf |publisher=Schwann |page=463 |oclc=463148605}}</ref> However, Ausbau languages must have different dialect basis,<ref>{{cite book|last=Kloss |first=Heinz |authorlink=Heinz Kloss |editor1-last=Göschel |editor1-first=Joachim |editor2-last=Nail |editor2-first=Norbert |editor3-last=van der Elst |editor3-first=Gaston |title=Zur Theorie des Dialekts: Aufsätze aus 100 Jahren Forschung |publisher=F. Steiner |pages=310, 312 |chapter=Abstandsprachen und Ausbausprachen |trans-chapter=Abstand-languages and Ausbau-languages |series=Zeitschrift fur Dialektologie and Linguistik, Beihefte, n.F., Heft 16 |location=Wiesbaden |year=1976 |oclc=2598722}}</ref> whereas Croatian, Bosnian, Montenegrin and Serbian standard variants have the same dialect basis ([[Shtokavian dialect|Štokavian]]):<ref>{{cite book|last=Blum |first=Daniel| year=2002 |language=German |title=Sprache und Politik : Sprachpolitik und Sprachnationalismus in der Republik Indien und dem sozialistischen Jugoslawien (1945-1991) |trans-title=Language and Policy: Language Policy and Linguistic Nationalism in the Republic of India and the Socialist Yugoslavia (1945-1991) |series=Beiträge zur Südasienforschung ; vol. 192 |location=Würzburg |publisher=Ergon |page=200 |isbn=3-89913-253-X |oclc=51961066}}</ref>
{{blockquote| The problems of the so-called Ausbau-languages in Heinz Kloss’s terminology are similar, but by no means identical to the problems of variants. In Ausbau-languages we have pairs of standard languages built on the basis of different dialects [...]. The difference between these paired Ausbau-languages and standard language variants lies in the fact that the variants have a nearly identical material (dialectal) basis and the difference is only in the development of the standardisation process, while paired standard languages have a more or less distinct dialect base.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brozović |first=Dalibor |authorlink=Dalibor Brozović |editor1-last=Bugarski |editor1-first=Ranko |editor2-last=Hewkesworth |editor2-first=Celia |title=Language Planning in Yugoslavia |publisher=Slavica Publishers |pages=72–79 |chapter=The Yugoslav Model of Language Planning: A Confrontation with Other Multilingual Models |location=Columbus, Ohio |year=1992 |oclc=26860931}}</ref> }}
{{blockquote| Kloss contrasts Ausbau languages not only with Abstand languages but also with polycentric standard languages (Stewart 1968<ref>{{cite book|last=Stewart |first=William A. |author-link=William Alexander Stewart |editor1-last=Fishman |editor1-first=Joshua A | editor1-link=Joshua A. Fishman |title=Readings in the Sociology of Language |publisher=Mouton |pages=529–545 |chapter=A Sociolinguistic Typology for Describing National Multilingualism |location=The Hague, Paris |year=1968 |doi=10.1515/9783110805376.531 |isbn=978-3-11-080537-6 |oclc=306499}}</ref>), i.e. two variants of the same standard, such as Serbo-Croatian and Portuguese in Brazil and Portugal. In contrast, pairs such as Czech and Slovak, Bulgarian and Macedonian, and Danish and Swedish, are instances of literary standards based on different dialects.<ref>{{cite book|last=Cooper |first=Robert Leon |year=1989 |title=Language planning and social change |location=Cambridge, New York |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=216 |oclc=19624070}}</ref> }}
On the contrary, the Serbo-Croatian kind of language secessionism is now a strongly consensual and institutional majority phenomenon. Still, this doesn't make it legitimate to say that such a language secessionism has led to "[[Ausbau language]]s" in the cases of Croatian, Bosnian, Montenegrin and Serbian, because such diversion has not taken place:<ref>{{cite book|last=Kafadar |first=Enisa |editor1-last=Henn-Memmesheimer |editor1-first=Beate |editor2-last=Franz |editor2-first=Joachim |title=Die Ordnung des Standard und die Differenzierung der Diskurse; Teil 1 |publisher=Peter Lang |pages=100–101, 103 |language=German |chapter=Bosnisch, Kroatisch, Serbisch – Wie spricht man eigentlich in Bosnien-Herzegowina? |trans-chapter=Bosnian, Croatian, Serbian – How do people really speak in Bosnia-Herzegovina? |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=63hKaFGtTDAC&pg=PA95&lpg=false#v=onepage&q&f=false |location=Frankfurt am Main |year=2009 |oclc=699514676 |accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Kordić, Snježana |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |title=Plurizentrische Sprachen, Ausbausprachen, Abstandsprachen und die Serbokroatistik |trans-title=Pluricentric languages, Ausbau languages, Abstand languages and the Serbo-Croatistics |url=http://www.zeitschrift-fuer-balkanologie.de/index.php/zfb/article/view/203/203 |language=German |journal=Zeitschrift für Balkanologie |volume=45 |issue=2 |pages=210–215 |year=2009 |issn=0044-2356 |oclc=680567046 |id={{ZDB|201058-6}} |archivedate= 4 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69f5bCgpH?url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/436361.AUSBAU-ABSTAND-PLURIZENTRISCH.PDF |accessdate=2 March 2014 |df= }}</ref>
{{blockquote| The intercomprehension between these standards exceeds that between the standard variants of English, French, German, or Spanish.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Thomas, Paul-Louis |title=Le serbo-croate (bosniaque, croate, monténégrin, serbe): de l’étude d’une langue à l’identité des langues |trans-title=Serbo-Croatian (Bosnian, Croatian, Montenegrin, Serbian): from the study of a language to the identity of languages |url=http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/slave_0080-2557_2002_num_74_2_6801 |language=French |journal=Revue des études slaves |volume=74 |issue=2-3 |page=325 |year=2003 |issn=0080-2557 |oclc=754204160 |id= {{ZDB|208723-6}} |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> }}
== In Galician-Portuguese == {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2016}} The [[Portugal|Portuguese kingdom]], a former southern county split from the [[Kingdom of Galicia]] and fief of the [[Kingdom of Leon]], was created by [[Afonso I of Portugal]] in 1126 and expanded towards the [[Al-Andalus|Islamic south]], like its neighbouring kingdoms. That part of Galicia, named Portugal, became independent while the northern part of the country remained under the [[Kingdom of León]] during the 12th century and early 13th century. Northern Galicia would later be ruled by the [[Crown of Castile|Kingdom of Castile]], which would become the core and ethnic base for the future [[Spain]]; but the culture was the same on both sides of the political border. Galician-Portuguese culture attained great [[Prestige (sociolinguistics)|prestige]] during the [[Low Middle Ages]]. In the late 15th century, Castilian domination became harder, [[Minoritized language|banishing their language]] in all official uses, including the [[Liturgical language|church]].
[[Galician-Portuguese]] survived [[Diglossia|diglossically]] for the following centuries among the peasant population, but it experienced a strong Spanish [[Superstratum|influence]] and had a different evolution.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} Meanwhile, the same language (for the [[Reintegrationism|reintegrationist]] view) remained fully [[Official language|official]] in Portugal and was carried across the world by [[Portuguese explorers]], soldiers and [[Portuguese colonies|colonists]].
During the 19th century a [[Linguistic revival|revival movement]] arose. This movement defended the Galician language, and created a provisional norm, with a Castilian [[orthography]] and many [[Loanword|loanwords]]. When autonomy was granted, a norm and orthography (based in ''rexurdimento'' writers) ([[Galician language literature|Galician literature]]) for a Galician language was created. This norm is taught and used in schools and [[List of universities in Spain|universities of Galicia]]. But most writers ([[Castelao]], [[Risco]], Otero Pedrayo) did not support the traditional Galician forms;{{Clarify|date=February 2009}} some of them based in Spanish orthography even if they recognized the essential linguistic unity, saying that the priority was achieving [[political autonomy]] and being [[Literacy|read by the population]]. Other writers wrote with a Portuguese-like orthography (e.g. Guerra da Cal and Carvalho Calero).
Reintegrationists claim that the official norm (released in 1982) was imposed by the Spanish state, with the covert intent of severing Galician from Portuguese. But this idea is rejected by the [[Royal Galician Academy|Real Academia Galega]], which supports the official norm.
[[Reintegrationism|Reintegrationist and Lusist groups]] are protesting against this so-called language secessionism, which they call Castrapism (from ''[[castrapo]]'', something like "[[patois]]") or [[Isolationism]]. Unlike in the case of [[Valencia|Valencian]] [[Blaverism]], isolationism has no impact in the scientific community of linguists, and it is supported for a small number of them but still has clear political support.
Galician-Portuguese linguistic unity until the 16th century seems to be consensus,{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} as does both Galician and European Portuguese being closer to each other and to the more conservative [[Portuguese dialects|Portuguese variants]] of [[Brazilian Portuguese|Brazil]] and [[Portuguese in Africa|Africa]] in the 18th century than in the 19th century, and also closer in the 19th century than in the 20th century and now. In this period, while Galician for the most part lost vowel reduction, [[velarization]] of {{IPA|/l/}} and [[Nasal vowel|nasal vowels]], and some speech [[Register (sociolinguistics)|registers]] of it adhered to ''[[yeísmo]]'', all making it phonologically closer to Spanish. For example, [[European Portuguese]] had splits that created two new [[vowel]] [[Phoneme|phonemes]], one of them usually an [[allophone]] only in the case of [[vowel reduction]] and the other phonetically absent in any other variant. Some dialects had a merger of three of its oral [[Diphthong|diphthongs]] and another three of its nasal vowels, and together with [[Brazilian Portuguese]] absorbed more than 5000 loanwords from [[French language|French]] as well as 1500 from [[English language|English]].
It seems that the debate for a greater integration among [[List of countries where Portuguese is an official language|Portuguese-speaking countries]] had the result of a single writing standard ([[1990 Portuguese Language Orthographic Agreement]]), often shunned by some segments of [[Media of Portugal|Portuguese media]] and population but long waited and cheered by Brazilians despite occasional criticism to some aspects and that changed the spelling of between 0.5% and 1% of the words in both former varieties, with minor respect to major dialect phonological differences. The other debate, whether Galician should use the same standard of Portuguese ([[Lusism]]), a standard with minor differences ([[Reintegrationism]]), a re-approximation of both through another [[Lusophone]] spelling agreement that would give particular regional differences such as that of Galician as well as major diverging dialects of Portuguese (especially in South America) more room (Reintegrationism), or the present standard based on the Spanish orthography, still did not cast official attention of government authorities in any of the involved countries, even if Lusophone support is expected to be strong in any of the first three cases.
A point often held by minorities among both Reintegrationists/Lusists and Lusophonists is that Portuguese should have a more conservative and uniform international speech standard that at the same time respected minor phonological differences between its [[Varieties of Portuguese|variants]] (such as a complete free choice of the various allophones of the [[rhotic consonant]] {{IPA|/ʁ/}}, {{IPA|[a ~ ɐ ~ ɜ ~ ə]}} for {{IPA|/a ~ ɐ/}} or {{IPA|[s ~ s̻ʲ ~ ʃ ~ ɕ]}} for the [[Voicelessness|voiceless]] allophone of {{IPA|/S/}}) that would further strength Lusophone integration (while sung European Portuguese is comprehensible to untrained Brazilians, this is not the case for even the media standard of Galician, let alone more colloquial varieties){{Citation needed|date=July 2014}}, but this is not especially welcomed by any party in Europe, much because as the adoption of the 1990 OA in 2009–2012 proved, the Portuguese are often very [[wikt:reticent|reticent]] of the adoption of things seen as giving preference, even if minor, to Brazil.
==In Tagalog== Republic Act No. 7104, approved on August 14, 1991, created the Commission on the [[Filipino language|Filipino Language]], reporting directly to the President and tasked to undertake, coordinate and promote researches for the development, propagation and preservation of Filipino and other [[Philippine languages]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chanrobles.com/republicactno7104.htm |title=Commission on the Filipino Language Act |publisher=Chan Robles Law Library |accessdate=2007-07-19}}</ref> On May 13, 1992, the commission issued Resolution 92-1, specifying that Filipino is the{{quote|text=...indigenous written and spoken language of [[Metro Manila]] and [[List of cities in the Philippines|other urban centers]] in the Philippines used as the language of communication of [[Ethnic groups in the Philippines|ethnic group]]s.<ref name="Res921">{{cite web|url=http://wika.pbworks.com/Resolusyon%20Blg%2092-1 |title=Resolusyon Blg. 92-1 |publisher=Commission on the Filipino Language |date=13 May 1992 |accessdate=2007-03-24 |language=Filipino}}</ref>}}
Though the [[Commission on the Filipino Language]] recognizes that a lot of the vocabulary of [[Filipino language|Filipino]] is based on [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]], the latest definition given to the national language tries to evade the use of the term ''Tagalog''.
According to some [[Filipinology|Filipinologists]] (people who specialize in the study of Filipino as a language), the main reason that Filipino is distinct from Tagalog is that in Filipino, there is a presence of vocabulary coming from other [[Philippine languages]], such as [[Cebuano language|Cebuano]] (such as ''bana'' - husband), [[Hiligaynon language|Hiligaynon]] (such as ''buang'' - insane) and [[Ilocano language|Ilocano]] (such as ''ading'' - little brother). They also maintain that the term [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] is the language of the [[Katagalugan]] or the [[Tagalog Republic|Tagalog Region]] and [[Linguistic purism|puristic]] in a sense. It lacks certain phonemes like /f/ and /v/, which makes it incapable of producing some indigenous proper nouns ''I'''f'''ugao'' and ''I'''v'''atan''.<ref name="Res921"/> Curiously, proponents of language secessionism are unable to account for the glaring absence of long vowel, phonemic in [[Tausug language|Tausug]], in Filipino phonology or for the absence of a [[schwa]]. Arguments for secessionism generally ignore the fact that the various [[languages of the Philippines]] have divergent phonologies.
== In Chinese ==
=== Mandarin versus other dialects === Among [[Chinese language|Chinese]] speakers, [[Cantonese]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://unravellingmag.com/articles/cantonese/|title=Cantonese: Language or dialect? {{!}} Unravel Magazine|work=Unravel|access-date=2018-04-17|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Hokkien]] and other [[varieties of Chinese]] are often referred to as [[dialect]]s ({{Lang-zh|c=方言|s=|t=}}), instead of [[language]]s ({{Lang-zh|c=|s=语言|t=語言}}), despite the fact that those languages/dialects are hard to understand for [[Mandarin Chinese|Mandarin]] speakers who are the majority of [[Chinese language|Chinese]] speakers unless they write things down. There are debates over whether those varieties of the [[Chinese language]] should be separate languages.
=== In Hokkien === In the [[Hokkien]] dialect ({{Lang-zh|c=|s=|t=閩南語}}) , which is widely used in [[Fujian]], [[Taiwan]], and other areas, it is debated that whether [[Taiwanese Hokkien|Taiwanese dialect]] ({{Lang-zh|c=|s=|t=臺灣閩南語}}) should be separated from the Hokkien language as the [[Taiwanese language]] ({{Lang-zh|c=|s=|t=臺灣話 or 臺語}}),<ref>{{Citation|last=民視綜合頻道|title=台語更名「閩南語」 學者批歧視－民視新聞|date=2011-05-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WweOAI4XH8c|accessdate=2018-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.peoplenews.tw/news/c239aeb3-bf18-42b6-8fbe-1b15f9a9cfe4|title=【民報】台灣南社 台灣羅馬字協會：「台語就是台語」不是閩南語|access-date=2018-04-17|language=zh-TW}}</ref> although people from Fujian and Taiwan can communicate with each other despite some differences in vocabulary. Such debates may be associated with [[Politics of the Republic of China|politics of Taiwan]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.storm.mg/lifestyle/285388|title=北京話不是國語、台語也不能叫閩南語！他這樣控訴國民黨對台灣歷史記憶的操弄…-風傳媒|last=Storm.mg|access-date=2018-04-17|language=zh-TW}}</ref>
However, some scholars believe that Hokkien should be the most standard accent of Chinese in history, regarding the [[Standard Chinese]] based on [[Beijing dialect|Beijing accent]] as an alienized dialect deeply influenced by [[Ethnic minorities in China|non-Han minorities]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.taiwanus.net/history/1/57.htm|title=台灣話的由來|website=www.taiwanus.net|access-date=2018-04-17}}</ref>

[[File:Seymour Simckes 1996.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Simckes, while on a Fulbright to Israel, 1996]] '''Lazarre Seymour Simckes''' is an award-winning playwright, novelist, educator, [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]-English translator, and [[psychotherapist]]. He has developed approaches to the use of creative writing in areas including prison therapy and cross-cultural communication between students in the [[Middle East]].
==Life and works== Simckes, descended from a long line of [[rabbi]]s (including his father Herbert Isaac Simckes, grandfather [[Mnachem Risikoff]] and great-grandfather [[Zvi Yosef Resnick]]), was born in [[Saratoga Springs, New York]],<ref name="Seven">Simckes, L.S., ''Seven Days of Mourning'', Random House, 1963, "About the Author"</ref> and raised in [[Boston]].<ref name="writers">[http://www.pw.org/content/lazarre_simckes Writers and Poets: Writers directory], retrieved February 7, 2011.</ref> He is a graduate of [[Harvard College]] (Magna Cum Laude, [[Phi Beta Kappa]]), [[Stanford University]] (Wallace Stegner Writing Fellow, M.A.), and [[Harvard University]] (Ph.D.).<ref name="BW">[http://offbroadway.broadwayworld.com/article/Next_NEW_CITY_NEW_BLOOD_READINGS_SERIES_Takes_Place_316_20090304 BroadwayWorld.com]</ref> He has taught at colleges and universities throughout the United States including Harvard, [[Yale]], [[Williams College|Williams]], [[Vassar College|Vassar]], [[Brandeis University|Brandeis]] and [[Tufts University|Tufts]], as well as at [[Bar-Ilan]] and the [[University of Haifa]] in Israel.<ref name="BW"/> He has also conducted live, interactive writing workshops via satellite linking middle school and high school students across the country, including the [[Virgin Islands]]. During his [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright]] year at the University of Haifa, he conducted a similar workshop linking Israeli Arab and Jewish high school students with their counterparts in America ("Celebrating Differences").<ref name="BW"/><ref name="fulbright">"Bridging Differences," ''The Israel Fulbrighter'', pg 7, 1995-1996, Israel.</ref>
===Playwright=== His first play, ''Seven Days of Mourning'' (adapted from his novel published by Random House), was staged on [[Broadway theater|Broadway]] at [[Circle in the Square Theatre|Circle in the Square]]. Clive Barnes called it "spiky, yet intensely moving. A ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'' without music, but with blood. Unique, wild, funny. It still haunts me." He wrote the off-off-Broadway play ''Ten Best Martyrs of the Year'', a [[Theater for the New City]] (TNC) production directed by Crystal Field, about the ten rabbis who were tortured to death in Rome for supporting the revolt led by [[Simon bar Kokhba|Bar Kokhbah]] in 2nd century Palestine. Simckes said of that play, "I tend to make tragic comment in a mixture of styles. So what did I do? I wrote a play as if through the eyes of Hadrian, the Roman emperor, watching the genocide of the Jews from his balcony."<ref name="tallmer">Tallmer, Jerry, [http://www.thevillager.com/villager_52/nossigsanticsat.html "Nossig's Antics at Theater for the New City"], ''The Villager'', May 4, 2004, retrieved February 7, 2011.</ref> The play was reviewed by Michael Smith in ''[[The Village Voice]]'' as "timeless, mythic, enlivened by all kinds of stylistic intrusions and an almost hysterical inventiveness."<ref name="bw">[http://offoffbroadway.broadwayworld.com/article/TNCs_New_City_New_Blood_Series_Premieres_SOLDIER_BOYS_119_20091108 BroadwayWorld.com], retrieved February 7, 2011.</ref> [[File:Seymour Simckes 1968.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1969]] [[File:Seymour Simckes 2009.jpg|thumb|left|New Haven, Connecticut, 2009]]
Another of his off-off-Broadway productions, ''Nossig's Antics'', also a TNC production directed by Crystal Field, focuses on the character of Alfred Nossig, who was accused of collaborating with Nazis in the [[Warsaw Ghetto]], and executed in 1943, just before his 80th birthday, by a Jewish fighters organization.<ref name="mcbee">McBee, Richard, [http://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/16311 ''The Jewish Press''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101228144015/http://www.jewishpress.com/pageroute.do/16311/ |date=2010-12-28 }}, June 2, 2004, retrieved February 7, 2011.</ref> The critic Richard McBee called it "a riveting puzzle,"<ref name="BW"/> and it has also been described as a "dark farce" and an "absurd exploration of history and the horrific times we live in."<ref name="mcbee"/>
His other plays include ''Minutes'', a fictional encounter between [[Sigmund Freud]] and [[Gustav Mahler]]; "Soldier Boys" about [[Nicholas I of Russia|Czar Nicholas]]'s 1827 edict to recruit Jews into the Russian army for the first time, including children as Cadets, which had a reading at Theater for the New City with Judd Hirsch as the Czar; and "Open Rehearsal," chosen by [[Edward Albee]] as first runner-up in the inaugural 2006-2007 Yale Drama Series Competition,<ref name="BW"/> He also wrote the screenplay for [[Sidney Lumet]]'s movie version of ''[[The Last Temptation of Christ]]'', which has not yet been produced.<ref name="tallmer"/>
===Novelist and translator=== Simckes's first published work was a translation of two stories by the Israeli author, [[S. Y. Agnon]], followed by the short story, "Behold My Servant!", published in Stanford Short Stories 1962.<ref name="Seven"/> His novels include ''Seven Days in Mourning'' and ''The Comatose Kids''. He has translated a number of works from Hebrew to English, including ''[[Adam Resurrected]]'',<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,905398,00.html "Books:Rags and Bones," July 19, 1971, Time.com.]</ref> ''The Chocolate Deal'',<ref>[http://wsupress.wayne.edu/books/625/Chocolate-Deal Book Review, Wayne State University Press.]</ref> and ''Commander of the Exodus''.<ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fact+and+Fiction+by+Yoram+Kaniuk.-a070450990 TheFreeLibrary.com.]</ref> He also translated Nava Semel's children's book, "Becoming Gershona," about a twelve-year-old girl in 1958 [[Tel Aviv]].<ref>[http://www.alibris.com/booksearch?qwork=607289&matches=33&browse=1&subject=Tel+Aviv+Israel&cm_sp=works*listing*title Alibris.com], retrieved February 7, 2011.</ref>
In addition to Hebrew, Simckes is fluent in [[Yiddish]], and according to the director of the film ''Kvetch'', [[Austin Kase]], Simckes was one of the inspirations for the movie, and also appeared in it.<ref>Claudell, Matthew, [http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2010/oct/08/kvetch-director-schvitzes-out-movie "Kvetch director schvitzes out a movie"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227043615/http://www.yaledailynews.com/news/2010/oct/08/kvetch-director-schvitzes-out-movie/ |date=2011-02-27 }}, October 8, 2010, ''Yale News''</ref>
===Psychotherapist=== As a practicing psychotherapist, Simckes has worked with multi-problem families and imprisoned [[sex offender]]s.<ref name="BW"/>
An article in ''The Israeli Fulbrighter'' notes that Simckes found a "dual vocation as a writer and healer."<ref name="fulbright"/> After studying at the Kantor Family Institute in Cambridge, Massachusetts, he began using brief writing assignments with patients in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, to help them deal with their problems. He continued working on this idea and eventually launched writing workshops in community centers, "attempting to foster literacy, empathy, listening skills, insight, respect, and resolution of conflict." He believes writing exercises are especially effective because "they serve to highlight the problem in a way that it can be dealt with."<ref name="fulbright"/>
===Cross-cultural educator=== Simckes has tried to bring all his talents and experiences to bear in his efforts among Israelis and Palestinians. He made "fostering cross-cultural insights and empathy" in the "interlocked perspectives surrounding the Arab/Israeli encounter" the core of his Fulbright year in Israel, at the University of Haifa.<ref name="fulbright"/> [[File:Seymour Simckes.jpg|thumb|right|Simckes standing on bridge over Charles River, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1963]]
Among his initiatives were a creative writing seminar, "The Mirror of Fiction", and a two-way live interactive video workshop, "Celebrating Differences", broadcast on February 27, 1996. The live interactive TV seminar linked American high school students in the United States with Jewish and Arab students (both Israeli and Palestinian) in Israel. "He created a live bridge and prompted the participants to share their experiences on handling differences," helping the students gain new insights about one another.<ref name="fulbright"/>
To prepare for the Israeli video program, broadcast through the Massachusetts Corporation for Educational Telecommunications, Simckes made frequent visits to [[Nazareth]], [https://web.archive.org/web/20101210073610/http://www.beit-hagefen.com/En_Web/En_%20Home_Index.htm Beit Hagefen], and [[Jish]] to find students who were comfortable with writing spontaneously, and sharing their writing on the air—and prepared to listen, not just "to yell at each other."<ref name="fulbright"/>
==== Use of language ==== Simckes has strong feelings about the use of English in workshops that involve both Israeli and Palestinians, because it is a "bridge language" and a "diffuser of power" in a political sense, interrupting "the implication of power through language."<ref name="fulbright"/>
He believes that the ability to listen is critical to both writing and healing, and hopes his writing workshops strengthen that skill. If people "can hear each other," he says, "they become a community."<ref name="fulbright"/>
==Awards== His awards include two National Endowment of the Arts fellowships and the National Jewish Book Award, as well as receiving the Best Actor award for his performance in the award-winning Comedy short-film, Kvetch.<ref name="fulbright"/>
==Books== *Seven Days of Mourning, Random House, 1963, Library of Congress Catalog Number 63-16151 *The Comatose Kids, University of Alabama Press, 1975, {{ISBN|978-0-914590-19-4}}
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsS/simckes-lazarre-seymour.html Simckes play database.] *{{YouTube|xcaOjgAOHsw|Film trailer, "Kvetch."}} (Note: Simckes is first actor seen in trailer.)

'''Literary presses''' are [[publishing|publishing companies]] that publish books with a literary or artistic emphasis. This is a list of publishing companies and imprints whose primary emphasis is on literature and the arts. It does not include exclusively online publishers, academic publishers (who often publish very limited print runs, but for a different market), or businesses operating solely as printers, such as [[print-on-demand]] companies or [[vanity press]]es. {{dynamic list}} ==List of English-language literary presses== <!-- DO NOT add publishers to this list if they do not already have an article (or major article section) on Wikipedia, or are not likely to have an article written about them in the future based on their CURRENT notability. For publishers without articles, at least one reference must be provided showing notability as a small press publisher in English, or they WILL be removed from the list --> * [[Algonquin Books]] * [[Arte Publico Press]] * [[Atlantic Books]] * [[Bellevue Literary Press]] * [[Blackwell Publishers]] * [[Coffee House Press]] * [[Etruscan Press]] * [[Faber and Faber]] * [[Four Walls Eight Windows]] * [[Gival Press]] * [[Graywolf Press]] * [[Harbor Mountain Press]] * [[Inanna Publications]] * [[Legend Press]] * [[Mercury House (publishers)|Mercury House]] * [[Milkweed Editions]] * [[Moschatel Press]] * [[New Rivers Press]] * [[Picador (imprint)|Picador]], a division of [[Henry Holt and Company]] * [[Sarabande Books]] * [[Small Beer Press]] * [[Southwick House]] * [[Tarpaulin Sky Press]] * [[TSAR Publications]] * [[Tupelo Press]] * [[Turnstone Press]] * [[Two Dollar Radio]] * [[Unnamed Press]] * [[Washington Writers Publishing House]]
==See also== {{cat see also|Literary presses}} *[[List of English-language small presses]] *[[List of English-language book publishing companies]]
