'''Western media''' is the [[mass media]] of the [[Western world]]. During the [[Cold War]], Western media contrasted with [[Soviet media]]. Western media has gradually expanded into [[developing countries]] (non-Western countries).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chadha|first=K.|author2=Kavoori, A. |title=Media imperialism revisited: some findings from the Asian case|journal=Media, Culture & Society|date=1 July 2000|volume=22|issue=4|pages=415–432|doi=10.1177/016344300022004003|url=http://mcs.sagepub.com/content/22/4/415.short}}</ref>
== History == The roots of the Western media can be traced back to the late 15th century, when [[printing press]]es began to operate throughout [[Western Europe]]. The emergence of [[news media]] in the 17th century has to be seen in close connection with the [[spread of the printing press]], from which the publishing [[Publishing|press]] derives its name.<ref>{{Citation | last = Weber | first = Johannes | title = Strassburg, 1605: The Origins of the Newspaper in Europe | journal = German History | volume = 24 | issue = 3 | pages = 387–412 (387) | year = 2006 | doi=10.1191/0266355406gh380oa}}: {{quote|At the same time, then as the printing press in the physical technological sense was invented, 'the press' in the extended sense of the word also entered the historical stage. The phenomenon of publishing was now born.}}</ref>
In Britain, newspapers developed during a period of political upheaval that challenged the absolute rule of the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|English Monarchy]]. In 1641, newspapers were allowed to publish domestic news for the first time.<ref name=hardy1/> Despite strict controls placed by the political elite on the print media to restrict the expansion of the press, the print industry continued to grow. By the late 18th century, over 10 million newspapers were distributed annually in Britain alone.<ref name=hardy1>{{cite book|last=Hardy|first=Jonathan|title=Western media systems|year=2008|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0203869048|pages=27–28}}</ref>
Bosah Ebo writes that "During the [[Cold War]], the United States and Soviet Union engaged in an intense media diplomacy aimed to create international image of each other."<ref>Bosah Ebo, "Media Diplomacy and Foreign Policy: Toward a Theoretical Framework" in ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QboMgCKGqUEC&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false News Media and Foreign Relations: A Multifaceted Perspective]'' (ed. Abbas Malek: Greenwood, 1997), pp. 48.</ref> [[Voice of America]] and [[Radio Free Europe]] were established by the U.S. as counterpoints to the Communist-dominated news media in the [[Eastern Bloc]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aeon.co/essays/cold-war-propaganda-the-truth-belonged-to-no-one-country|title=Cold War propaganda: the truth belonged to no one country|work=Aeon|author=Melissa Feinberg|date=December 11, 2017}}</ref> Scholar James Schwoch writes, "Western-inspired television programming and development in Cold War Germany and Europe began as not so much a case of the unfettered free flow of information from West to East, but rather as a strong counterbalance preventing, or discouraging, the Soviet-sourced first flow of the European television landscape."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bFCbAn5j6gIC&pg=PA41|title=Global TV: New Media and the Cold War, 1946-69|last=Schwoch|first=James|date=2009|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=9780252075698|location=|pages=41}}</ref>
During the [[Cold War]], Western media outlets were gradually accepted as a trustworthy and reliable source of news. In former [[East Germany]], surveys showed that over 91% of [[Eastern Bloc emigration and defection|migrants]] perceived Western media outlets to be more reliable than East German media outlets.<ref name="de Gruyter">{{cite book|authors=H. J. Bretz, R. Weber, G. Gmel & B. Schmitz|editors=Rainer K. Silbereisen & Alexander von Eye|title=Growing up in times of social change|year=1999|publisher=de Gruyter|location=Berlin [u.a.]|isbn=978-3110165005|page=2015–06}}</ref>
In recent years, many Western media outlets have seen their circulation figures stagnate.<ref name="Simone Pieranni">{{cite web |last=Simone Pieranni|title=Western Media In Crisis, But What About China?|url=http://en.ejo.ch/6304/media_economics/western-press-crisis-china|publisher=[[European Journalism Observatory]]|accessdate=12 December 2013}}</ref>
==Characteristics == ''[[New Left Review]]'' editor [[Tariq Ali]] asserts that "the notion of a free press in the Western media in the 20 century evolved as a counterpoint to the monopolistic State-owned model of erstwhile Soviet Union with the aim of showing its superiority by accommodating diversity of voices. In terms of what it published and what it showed, the Western media gained its peak during the Cold War era."<ref name="hindu1">{{cite news |title='Without free flow of information, there can be no serious democracy' |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/without-free-flow-of-information-there-can-be-no-serious-democracy/article4898966.ece |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=12 December 2013 |date=July 10, 2013}}</ref>
=== Global coverage === [[File:Time magazine POY.jpg|thumb|In 2011, "The Protester" was named "[[Time Person of the Year|Person of the Year]]" by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine]]
* [[Africa]] – A 1997 study found that the American newsmagazine ''[[Newsweek]]'' and the German newsmagazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' regularly reported on Africa issues, but that "most of the news comes from [[List of ongoing armed conflicts|regions of conflict]] and can be regarded as crisis news."<ref name="Annas">{{cite journal|last=Rolf Annas|title=News flow out of Africa: are Western media striving for excellence in communication standards?|journal=Ecquid Novi: African Journalism Studies|date=1997|volume=18|issue=2|pages=196–208|doi=10.1080/02560054.1997.9653203}}</ref> The study found that "the ratio of crisis to non-crisis news" was more balanced in ''Newsweek'' than in ''Der Spiegel''.<ref name="Annas"/>
* [[Middle East]] – It has been claimed that past representations of Arabs in Western media have relied heavily on racial myths and [[Stereotypes of Arabs and Muslims in the United States|stereotypes]].<ref>{{cite book |editor=Yahya R. Kamalipour |title=Cultural diversity and the US media |year=1998 |publisher=State Univ. of New York Press |location=Albany |isbn=978-0791439296}}</ref>
===Coverage of military conflicts=== Criticisms of the [[media coverage of the Iraq War|media coverage leading up to]] the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] was been acute.<ref name="HayesGuardino">{{Cite journal|title=Whose Views Made the News? Media Coverage and the March to War in Iraq|author=Danny Hayes & Matt Guardino|journal=Political Communication|volume=27|date=2010|issue=1|pages = 59–87|doi = 10.1080/10584600903502615}}</ref> One study examined every evening television news story related to Iraq on [[ABC News|ABC]], [[CBS News|CBS]], and [[NBC News|NBC]]. The study found that "that news coverage conformed in some ways to the conventional wisdom: Bush administration officials were the most frequently quoted sources, the voices of anti-war groups and opposition Democrats were barely audible, and the overall thrust of coverage favored a pro-war perspective."<ref name="HayesGuardino"/> However, the study also found that "it is too facile to conclude that anti-war positions were completely marginalized. In contrast to the common critiques of media coverage, even as elites in the United States were not publicly sparring, journalists turned to foreign officials for the anti-war perspective."<ref name="HayesGuardino"/> The network media did commonly report "opposition from abroad—in particular, from Iraq and officials from countries such as France, who argued for a diplomatic solution to the standoff."<ref name="HayesGuardino"/>
Max Abrahms, writing in ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'', has criticized Western media's [[Media coverage of the Syrian Civil War|coverage of the Syrian Civil War]], arguing that it is overly favorable to the [[Syrian opposition]] and fails to take into account extremist elements within the opposition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/middle-east/2017-10-30/syrias-extremist-opposition|title=Syria's Extremist Opposition|last=Abrahms|first=Max|work=Foreign Affairs|date=October 30, 2017}}</ref>
===Coverage of human rights=== Coverage of global [[human rights]] increased in the media of the [[Global North]] between 1985 and 2000. A [[regression analysis]] of human rights reporting by the newsmagazines ''[[The Economist]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' found that "these two media sources cover abuses in human rights terms more frequently when they occur in countries with higher levels of state repression, economic development, population, and Amnesty International attention. There is also some evidence that political openness, number of battle-deaths, and civil societies affect coverage, although these effects were not robust."<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.howardramos.ca/index_htm_files/Ramos%20Ron%20Thoms%202007.pdf|title=Shaping the Northern Media's Human Rights Coverage, 1986–2000|authors=Howard Ramos, James Ron & Oskar N. T. Thoms|number=4|journal=Journal of Peace Research|date=July 2007}}</ref>
In 2008, an empirical analysis of the effects of "naming and shaming" of governments that are said to perpetrate human rights abuses (by media outlets as well as by governments and [[nongovernmental organizations]]) found that "governments put in the global spotlight for violations often adopt better protections for political rights afterward, but they rarely stop or appear to lessen acts of terror." The study also found that "In a few places, global publicity is followed by more repression in the short term, exacerbating leaders' insecurity and prompting them to use terror, especially when armed opposition groups or elections threaten their monopoly on power."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hafner-Burton|first=Emilie M.|date=October 2008|title=Sticks and Stones: Naming and Shaming the Human Rights Enforcement Problem|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/international-organization/article/sticks-and-stones-naming-and-shaming-the-human-rights-enforcement-problem/39C386310B323A85E58F4E687CA5F7D9|journal=International Organization|language=en|volume=62|issue=4|pages=689–716|doi=10.1017/S0020818308080247|issn=1531-5088|citeseerx=10.1.1.668.3134}}</ref>
=== Ownership patterns=== In the United States, the media is largely privately owned.<ref name="Janda">Kenneth Janda, Jeffrey Berry & Jerry Goldman, ''The Challenge of Democracy: Government in America'' (Centgage: 9th ed. 2008), pp. 167-68.</ref> In other democratic nations of the Western world, particularly in [[Western Europe]], print media outlets such as newspapers are usually privately owned, but [[public broadcasting]] is dominant in the broadcast media (radio and television).<ref name="Janda"/> Historically, the United States was the only developed nation that "created a broadcasting system that was [[Advertisement|advertiser]]-supported virtually from the start."<ref>Michael P. McCauley, "Introduction" in ''Public Broadcasting and the Public Interest'' (eds. Michael P. McCauley, Deedee Halleck, B. Lee Artz & Eric E. Peterson: M.E. Sharpe, 2003), p. 141.</ref> The contrasting Western European model sees public media as "a representation of the national culture."<ref>Katarzyna Konarska, "Globalisation, Local Media Markets and the Media Regulatory Systems of the Countries of Central and Eastern Europe: Main Aspects" in ''Media, Power and Empowerment: Central and Eastern European Communication and Media Conference 2012'' (eds. Tereza Pavlíčková & Irena Reifová: Conference Proceedings of the 5th Central and Eastern European Communication and Media Conference: Media, Power and Empowerment, Prague, Czech Republic, April 21-28, 2012).</ref>
=== Press freedom === [[Reporters Without Borders|Reporters Without Borders's]] [[Press Freedom Index]] scored the following countries the highest in 2018: [[Norway]], [[Sweden]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Finland]], [[Switzerland]], [[Jamaica]], [[Belgium]], [[New Zealand]], [[Denmark]], and [[Costa Rica]].<ref>{{cite web|title=2018 World Press Freedom Index|publisher=Reporters Without Borders|url=https://rsf.org/en/ranking}}</ref> [[UNESCO]] reported in 2014 that "the freedom to publish in the 27 countries of the Western Europe and North America region has remained strong and widely upheld."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0022/002277/227741e.pdf|title=World Trends in Freedom of Expression and Media Development: Regional Overview of Western Europe and North America|publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Communication and Information Sector|date=2014|page=7}}</ref>
== Criticism == In the 1970s, some scholars in communications studies, such as Oliver Boyd-Barrett, Jeremy Tunstall and [[Elihu Katz]], advanced a "[[media imperialism]]" perspective. This theory posits that there is an "iniquitous flow of cultural production from the First to the Third World ... whereby the media of advanced capitalist economies were able to substantially influence, if not actually determine, the nature of cultural production and consumption within Third World countries," leading to cultural hegemonization in favor of individualism and consumerism.<ref name="ChadhaKavoori">{{Cite journal|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/240707871|title=Media imperialism revisited: Some findings from the Asian case|author=Kalyani Chadha & Anandam P. Kavoori|journal=Media Culture & Society|date=July 2000|page=415–32|volume=22|issue=4}}</ref> [[Lee Kuan Yew]] of Singapore, [[Hindu nationalist]]s in India, and the Chinese authorities have all pressed for restrictions on Western media in their respective nations, viewing it as a possible threat to Asian values.<ref name="ChadhaKavoori"/> Other scholars, such as Fred Fejes, Daniël Biltereyst and [[Hamid Naficy]], have criticized the "media imperialism" theory, arguing that it arguing that it unjustifiably relies on a "[[hypodermic needle model]]" of media effects, overstates the influences of media on the audience's behavior and views, and romanticizes "national culture" unduly.<ref name="ChadhaKavoori"/>
===From China=== Following the Chinese [[2014 Kunming attack]], in which [[Uyghurs|Uyghur]] Muslim [[Xinjiang conflict|Xinjiang secessionists]] killed 31 people, Chinese state media and Chinese social media users criticized major Western media outlets that placed quotation marks around the word "terrorism" in news articles about the event.<ref name="Dawn, Yiqin Fu">Dawn, Yiqin Fu, [http://www.dawn.com/news/1091091 "Chinese are angry at western media's portrayal of the Kunming attack], ''Dawn'' (March 5, 2014).</ref> While some Chinese Internet users interpreted the quotation marks as attribution to the statements of the Chinese government, others accused the Western media of sympathizing with the separatists.<ref name="Dawn, Yiqin Fu"/> China accused "Western commentators, with their focus on Uighur rights, of hypocrisy and [[double standards]] on terrorism."<ref name="BBC News, Kunming, John Sudworth">BBC News, Kunming, John Sudworth, Mar 3, 2014 [https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-china-blog-26380542 "Shock and anger after Kunming brutality"], March 3, 2014.</ref>
===From Russia=== Russian media and government often claims that Western media is biased against Russia.<ref name="theguardian.com">New East network expert panel, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/04/western-media-coverage-ukraine-crisis-russia Is Western media coverage of the Ukraine crisis anti-Russian?], ''The Guardian'' (August 4, 2014).</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] wrote in 2018 that the Russian Foreign Ministry has promoted [[conspiracy theories]] about "the Western media" and denounced critical news coverage.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Emma Daly|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2018/05/03/rising-hostility-media-threatens-real-democracy-0|title=Rising Hostility to Media Threatens Real Democracy|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=May 3, 2018}}</ref> In 2005, Russia established [[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]] (later RT); [[Julia Ioffe]], writing in the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', writes that RT was established as a [[soft power]] and [[Russian propaganda|propaganda]] instrument, aimed at countering Western media outlets and promoting Russian foreign policy.<ref>Julia Ioffe, [https://archives.cjr.org/feature/what_is_russia_today.php What Is Russia Today?: The Kremlin's propaganda outlet has an identity crisis], ''Columbia Journalism Review'' (September/October 2010).</ref> In the second half of 2012, between 2.25 and 2.5 million Britons watched RT broadcasting (making it the third-most watched [[rolling news]] channel in Britain, behind [[BBC News]] and [[Sky News]]).<ref name="Bullough">Oliver Bullough [http://www.newstatesman.com/world-affairs/world-affairs/2013/05/inside-russia-today-counterweight-mainstream-media-or-putins-mou Inside Russia Today: counterweight to the mainstream media, or Putin's mouthpiece?], ''New Statesman'', May 10, 2013.</ref><ref name="Laughlin">Laughlin, Andrew, Jan 14, 2013 [http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/media/news/a450812/rt-russian-news-channel-goes-hd-on-sky.html RT Russian news channel goes HD on Sky], ''Digital Spy''.</ref> An article by Andrei P. Tsygankov on editorials in the ''[[New York Times]]'', ''[[Washington Post]]'', and ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' related to Russian domestic politics from 2008 to 2014 found that the editorials were overwhelmingly negative of the Russian government, based on such issues as "elections, opposition and minority rights, the justice system, protection of property rights, freedom of media, development of NGOs and civil society, protection of citizens against crime and terrorism, mechanisms for the transfer of power, attitudes of [[Vladimir Putin|Putin]] and [[Medvedev]], and relations with Western nations." Tsygankov asserted that the editorials failed to adequately reflect "neutral and positive frames and such as those stressing the country's relative progress or objective difficulties faced in its development."<ref>{{Cite journal|title=The dark double: the American media perception of Russia as a neo-Soviet autocracy, 2008–2014|author=Andrei P Tsygankov|volume=37|issue=1|pages = 19–35|journal=Politics|date=2017|doi = 10.1177/0263395715626945}}</ref> By contrast, James Nixey of the Russia and Eurasia Programme at [[Chatham House]] argued that fair reporting does not require [[False balance|false equivalence]] between Russian and Western actions, and that negative coverage of Russia was understandable given its [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|conduct in Crimea]], [[Russo-Georgian War|Georgia]], and [[Russian involvement in the Syrian Civil War|Syria]], and its poor human rights record.<ref name="theguardian.com"/> [[Piers Robinson]] argues that both Russian media and Western media is biased, writing "mainstream media, wherever it may be based, is widely acknowledged to be overly deferential to political and economic power and that means, as consumers of news."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/aug/02/russian-propaganda-western-media-manipulation|title=Russian news may be biased – but so is much western media|author=Piers Robinson|date=August 2, 2016|website=The Guardian}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Agenda-setting theory]] * [[Alternative media]] * [[Big Three television networks]] * [[Corporate media]] * [[Freedom of the press]] * [[Mainstream media]] * [[Media bias]] * [[Media conglomerate]] * [[Media cross-ownership in the United States]] * [[Media democracy]] * [[Media manipulation]] * [[Media proprietor]] * [[Media transparency]] * [[Old media]] * [[Propaganda model]] * [[State controlled media]]

|image = [[File:Logo Mujeres Poetas Internacional MPI, inc..jpg|200px|Logo MPI]] |imagestyle = |caption = Logo Women Poets International |captionstyle = |headerstyle = background:#ccf; |labelstyle = background:#ddf; |datastyle =
|header1 = References |Country = [[Santo Domingo]], [[Dominican Republic]] |Since = 2009 |header2 = |label2 = Description |data2 = Home of Woman Scream International Poetry Festival |header3 = |label3 = |data3 = Started at the [[Dominican Republic]] in 2009, by Mujeres Poetas Internacional MPI. Inc. |header4 = Additional Info |data4 = does not display (same number as a header) |header5 = |Year = 2009 |Month = November
|belowstyle = background:#ddf; |below = MPI holds Woman Scream International Poetry Festival since 2011 }}
The '''Women Poets International Movement''' (also known as '''Movimiento Mujeres Poetas Internacional MPI''') is an international non-profit organization operated out of the [[Dominican Republic]].<ref>{{cite news|title=International Women Poets Movement (MPI), Inc., and it grows each year as it is being translated into several languages thanks to the altruism of hundreds of people|url=http://www.dominicanaonline.org/portal/english/cpo_noti5414.asp|accessdate=14 August 2014|newspaper=Dominicana Online|date=2014-04-07}}</ref> It was first launched in 2009 and focuses on the promotion of female poets and poetry through collective projects, publications and events.
==Events== Women Poets International is a nonprofit foundation started in November 2009 at the Dominican Republic, committed to promoting the work of contemporary female poets internationally through collective projects, and with the social responsibility of sharing messages of respect, self-esteem and nonviolence against women. This foundation holds several events throughout the year,<ref name="KP">{{cite news|title="Britma e gruas" pro fuqizimit të zërit femëror|url=http://www.kosovapress.com/sq/arkiva/britma-e-gruas-pro-fuqizimit-te-zerit-femeror-161640/?old=1|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=Kosova Press|date=12 March 2013}}</ref> such as the ''Woman Scream International Poetry Festival'' celebrated in march of each year,<ref name="listindiario.com">{{cite news|title="Grito de Mujer" en Macorís del mar|url=http://www.listindiario.com/ventana/2012/3/3/223890/Grito-de-Mujer-en-Macoris-del-mar|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=Listin Diario|date=3 March 2012}}</ref> international poetry contests, and outdoor non-violence campaigns.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anuncian Jornada art|url=http://www.almomento.net/news/134/ARTICLE/101628/2011-12-06.html|publisher=Al Momento|accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref> The organization also lends assistance to various festivals, concerts, and conferences throughout the world.
===Woman Scream International Poetry Festival=== In 2009 the organization held their first ''Woman Scream International Poetry Festival'' (''Festival Internacional de Poesía Grito de Mujer'') in the [[Dominican Republic]].<ref name="listindiario.com"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Con un festival de poesía rindieron homenaje a las mujeres en su día|url=http://www.elliberal.com.ar/ampliada.php?ID=35523|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=El Liberal|date=2012-03-26}}</ref> The festival is held over the month of March and focuses on honoring women through multiple events. In 2011 Women Poets International expanded the focus of the event to also promote violence awareness due to the mutilation and murder of [[Mexican people|Mexican]] poet [[Susana Chávez]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Trujillo: Preparan II Festival Internacional de poesía Grito de Mujer|url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/2012-02-17-trujillo-preparan-ii-festival-internacional-de-poesia-grito-de-mujer-noticia_452170.html|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=Radio Programas del Perú|date=17 February 2012}}</ref> In 2013 the worldwide event honored [[Malala Yousafzai]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Celebran Segundo Festival Internacional de Poesía en San Pedro de Macorís|url=http://eldia.com.do/sociales/2012/4/3/79233/Celebran-Segundo-Festival-Internacional-de-Poesia-en-San-Pedro-de-Macoris|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=El Dia|date=3 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=VÉLEZ|first=PILAR|title=Descubra cómo se gestó "Grito de Mujer". Una entrevista a su fundadora, la poeta dominicana Jael Uribe|url=http://astrolabiumpress.com/descubra-como-se-gesto-grito-de-mujer-una-entrevista-a-su-fundadora-la-poeta-dominicana-jael-uribe/|publisher=Astrolabium Press|accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref>
The event is held simultaneously in several locations around the globe such as [[Spain]], [[Canada]], USA, [[Kosovo]], and other in Latin America, Asia and Europe.<ref name="KP" /> Typical events held include conferences, exhibitions, poetry recitals, competitions, and concerts.<ref>{{cite news|title=Planeta Mujeres|url=http://www.lostiempos.com/lecturas/varios/varios/20120311/%E2%80%9Cplaneta-mujeres%E2%80%9D_163550_342473.html|accessdate=8 September 2013|newspaper=Los Tiempos|date=10 March 2012}}</ref>
